title: 112_s2182
content: The "Child Care Public-Private Partnership Act of 2012" establishes a grant program for States and nonprofit organizations to support businesses in providing child care services. Grants are provided on a competitive basis to eligible businesses and consortia in States, as well as to nonprofit organizations with expertise in managing high-quality child care centers. To be eligible for a grant under the "Child Care Public-Private Partnership Act of 2012," a State or nonprofit business organization must submit an application to the Secretary with specified information. The application by a nonprofit business organization must include assurances of matching funds and proper expenditure of the grant. The applicant must assure the proper expenditure of grant funds for specified use, ensure affordable and equitable child care services for low- and moderate-income employees, comply with state and local licensing requirements, and provide technical information only to compliant businesses. The applicant must ensure grant funds are used properly for child care services, comply with licensing requirements, and prioritize businesses in underserved areas for grants. Grants awarded under section 2 must be used by States to provide funding to eligible businesses or consortia for start-up costs, employee child care assistance, and staff training. Businesses and consortia must apply for these grants. To be eligible for a grant under section 4, a business or consortium must submit an application to the State with required information. The application must include assurances on matching funds, proper fund usage, and implementation strategies. To be eligible for a grant under section 4, a business must provide assurances on affordable child care services, compliance with licensing requirements, and demonstrate a lack of licensed child care providers in the area. Priority will be given to businesses with fewer than 100 full-time employees. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "business" refers to a person engaged in commerce whose primary activity is not child care services. "Child care services" involve caring for a child at or near the parent's workplace, subsidized by the employer. A "consortium" is a partnership of two or more businesses and a nonprofit organization specializing in child care services. The term "Secretary" in this Act refers to the Secretary of Health and Human Services. Authorization of appropriations for $25,000,000 annually from 2013 to 2015 is provided in this Act.
